items.title: Global protests against Tesla CEO Elon Musk – video
items.summary: [Protesters gathered outside Tesla showrooms worldwide on Saturday as part of a global day of action against Elon Musk.]\n[The protest is part of the Tesla Takedown movement, which calls for a boycott of Tesla and local picketing.]\n[The campaign urges individuals to sell their shares and peacefully demonstrate against Musk’s influence.]

items.title: On my radar: George the Poet’s cultural highlights
items.summary:
- George the Poet, born George Mpanga in 1991, is a spoken-word artist and hosts the podcast [Have You Heard George’s Podcast?](https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/oct/07/the-week-in-radio-have-you-heard-georges-podcast-the-news-agents-investigates-sidetracked-with-annie-and-nick-uncanny-review).
- He will perform at [RISE at the Royal Festival Hall](https://www.southbankcentre.co.uk/whats-on/r-i-s-e/) on April 25, part of the Multitudes festival.
- He recommends [Kenya Kitchen](https://kenyakitchen.co.uk/) in Edgware for its authentic East African cuisine.
- He highlights Keys the Prince's music, noting the style and cultural relevance of his visual music videos.
- He discusses the [R Discovery](https://discovery.researcher.life/) app, which simplifies finding academic papers for his PhD studies.
- Ely Wananda’s YouTube channel, focusing on Black British life, is noted for its engaging content and important questions on social issues.
- George enjoys the second season of [Squid Game](https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2024/dec/26/squid-game-season-two-review-will-make-you-uncomfortably-bloodthirsty-netflix), appreciating its critique of capitalism.
- He recommends the children’s program [Kunda and Friends](https://www.youtube.com/@kundaandfriends) for its educational value and representation of African children.

items.title: Move fast, kill things: the tech startups trying to reinvent defence with Silicon Valley values
items.summary:
- Skydio is a leading US drone maker, focusing on military and civilian uses, with over $740m in funding.
- Investors have channeled nearly $155bn into global defence tech startups between 2021 and 2024, a significant rise from previous years.
- Defence startups emphasize the need for advanced technologies like AI and autonomy to meet modern military needs, contrasting with traditional defence corporations.

items.title: Emojis are now everywhere – but using them can be a minefield
items.summary:
- Emojis are rapidly becoming a new language, reflecting evolving forms of communication.
- Emoji culture is marked by varying perceptions; what one person views as patriotic can be seen by another as crass.
- The first emoticon was recorded in 1967, with significant milestones like the 1999 mainstreaming of emojis by Shigetaka Kurita.
- Miscommunication with emojis is common; for example, a simple smiley can convey sarcasm to younger generations.
- There are calls for the Oxford English Dictionary to include an emoji appendix due to their linguistic significance.

items.title: Birthday freebies: how to cash in on UK retailers’ gifts and discounts
items.summary:
- Retailers in the UK offer various gifts and discounts on customers' birthdays through loyalty programs and newsletters.
- Highlights include receiving free items like doughnuts from Greggs, muffins from Gail’s Bakery, and beauty gift bags from Space NK.
- Some stores require a minimum purchase or advance sign-up, while restaurants like Burger King offer free burgers.
- H&M and Nike provide discounts on products for members, while chocolate brands like Hotel Chocolat require a minimum spend for birthday rewards.

items.title: ‘Incel’ accounts using self-improvement language to avoid TikTok bans – study
items.summary:
- Advocates of incel ideology are rebranding as 'Sub5s' using self-improvement language on TikTok.
- Hateful content is banned on TikTok, but incel accounts disguise their messages as socially acceptable.
- Research by Anda Iulia Solea from Portsmouth highlights theories like the 80:20 rule of attraction and the PSL scale ranking men by attractiveness.
- The study analyzed videos from five TikTok accounts promoting incel theories.
- TikTok claims to strictly prohibit misogyny and actively removes violating content.

items.title: ‘Love the car, not the CEO’: how Europe’s Tesla owners feel about their cars - and Elon Musk
items.summary:
- Tesla showrooms expected to face anti-Elon Musk protests as backlash grows among European consumers.
- A 44% drop in Tesla sales in Europe reported, with market share falling to 9.6% in February.
- While the UK sees a 21% rise in Tesla registrations, owners voice their conflicted feelings about Musk's leadership and politics.

items.title: Elon Musk’s xAI firm buys social media platform X for $33bn
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI firm acquires X (formerly Twitter) for $33 billion.
- The all-stock deal values xAI at $80 billion and incorporates Musk's portfolio including Tesla and SpaceX.
- Musk stated the integration of data, models, and talent will enhance the capability of xAI's AI model, Grok.
- Details remain unclear about investor compensation and regulatory scrutiny.
- The acquisition is viewed as part of Musk consolidating management across his enterprises.
- xAI was launched two years ago and has raised $10 billion recently, achieving a valuation of $75 billion.
- Musk faces a lawsuit regarding alleged fraud against former Twitter shareholders for delayed investment disclosure.

items.title: Atomfall review – everybody’s gone to the reactor
items.summary:
- Atomfall presents a fictional scenario where a nuclear accident in the UK is depicted, inspired by real events like the Windscale fire.
- Players navigate a postwar Britain, awakening in an exclusion zone and working to unravel the mystery behind the disaster by collecting clues.
- The game features an underground research facility that players must reactivate to uncover secrets, with various quests leading to a more engaging narrative.
- Combat options are noted as serviceable but unremarkable, with a rudimentary crafting system mainly for basic needs.
- The atmosphere and setting, while visually appealing, lack depth and the game's representation of British culture feels superficial.

items.title: The best cordless vacuum cleaners for a spotless home: 10 tried and tested favourites
items.summary:
- This review compares 10 leading cordless vacuum cleaners across various price points, testing their effectiveness in cleaning up different types of messes like flour, cat litter, and pet hair.
- The top three vacuum cleaners recommended are:
  - Best overall: [Shark PowerDetect Clean & Empty IP3251](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.johnlewis.com%2Fshark-ip3251ukt-powerdetect-clean-autoempty-cordless-pet-vacuum-cleaner-java-perry%2Fp112561801&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/mar/28/best-cordless-vacuum-cleaners-uk) (£369.91 at John Lewis)
  - Best budget: [Vax HomePro Pet-Design](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.co.uk%2FVax-Pet-Design-Cordless-Motorised-CLSV-MPKA%2Fdp%2FB0DK7GHJTX&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/mar/28/best-cordless-vacuum-cleaners-uk) (£317 at Amazon)
  - Best for deep cleaning: [Dyson Gen5detect](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.johnlewis.com%2Fdyson-gen5detect-absolute-cordless-vacuum-cleaner-purple%2Fp110523878&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/mar/28/best-cordless-vacuum-cleaners-uk) (£649 at John Lewis)
- Testing involved evaluating cleaning power, battery life, and ease of use while handling different floor types.

items.title: Digested week: I agree with Jeremy Clarkson – my enemy’s enemy is still kind of a jerk
items.author: Emma Brockes
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's conflict with Jeremy Clarkson continues, with Clarkson mocking Tesla's current challenges.
- A judge ordered two RAF engineers to pay damages for vandalizing a Paddington bear statue, highlighting the symbolic nature of such actions.
- The Netflix show 'Adolescence' faces both praise and criticism as discussions about the portrayal of misogyny evolve.
- Concerns arise regarding travel to the US, as citizens share tips to avoid issues with customs.
- A babysitter's attempt to ease a child's fears turned dangerous when a man was found hiding under the bed, leading to his arrest.

items.title: The controversial California city backed by tech elite has a new plan: boats
items.summary:
- In 2023, California Forever proposed a new city in Solano County amidst local frustrations about outsider influence.
- Recently, they shifted focus to creating a shipbuilding hub on its 65,000 acres of land, aiming to revitalize the shipbuilding industry in the US.
- Local officials expressed enthusiasm for the maritime industry expansion, citing Solano's shipbuilding history and potential economic benefits.

items.title: Global anti-Elon Musk protests planned at nearly 200 Tesla showroom locations
items.summary:
- Hundreds of protests at Tesla showrooms are planned globally for Saturday as part of "Tesla Takedown’s Global Day of Action".
- Organizers aim to protest Elon Musk’s influence on the federal government, citing layoffs and budget cuts.
- Demonstrators plan to discourage purchasing Tesla vehicles and selling Tesla stock to weaken Musk's financial standing.
- Since Donald Trump's inauguration, Tesla's stock has dropped more than 35%, affecting Musk's net worth, which has decreased by $100 billion.
- The protests have expanded rapidly across cities in the US, with significant turnout expected for the upcoming demonstrations.

items.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles was the hardest game I ever played – so why am I back?
items.author: Dominik Diamond
items.summary:
- The author typically does not replay games but made an exception for Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, the hardest game they ever completed.
- Revisiting the game on PS4 brought back memories of challenging gameplay, especially the unforgiving collision detection.
- The article emphasizes the importance of persistence in gaming and the enjoyment found in overcoming difficulties, likening the experience to nostalgic gaming moments from childhood.

items.title: Italian government approved use of spyware on members of refugee NGO, MPs told
items.summary:
- The Italian government sanctioned surveillance on NGO members as potential national security threats.
- Surveillance involved Graphite spyware, made by Paragon Solutions, and was part of a classified investigation.
- Activists and journalists, including members of Mediterranea Saving Humans, received warnings about spyware targeting.
- Undersecretary Alfredo Mantovano stated the operation was legal and aimed at illegal immigration investigation.
- Five-city prosecutor inquiry is ongoing after multiple complaints from targets of the alleged spyware activity.

items.title: From Smash-Proof Cases to Updates: How to Make Your Smartphone Last Longer
items.author: Samuel Gibbs
items.summary:
- Modern smartphones can last up to seven years with proper care.
- A good quality case and screen protector can prevent damage from drops.
- Keeping the phone updated with the latest operating system is crucial for security and functionality.
- Regularly clearing out storage can help improve performance.
- Battery health can be maintained by avoiding extreme temperatures and planning for replacements after several years of use.
- Regular cleaning of the device is essential for hygiene and functionality.

items.title: These games were indie smash hits – but what happened next?
items.summary:
- In 2024, nearly 19,000 video games were released on Steam alone.
- Successful indie games like Balatro and Manor Lords showcase that small developers can break through despite challenges.
- Gabe Cuzzillo advises focusing on intrinsic success rather than external pressures for future projects.
- Grace Bruxner prioritizes personal pride and positive impact over traditional measures of success.
- The indiegame scene faces difficulties with funding and opportunities following recent industry turbulence.

items.title: As a geneticist, I will not mourn 23andMe and its jumble of useless health information
items.author: Adam Rutherford
items.summary:
- 23andMe has filed for bankruptcy, which the author finds unremarkable.
- The company capitalized on personal genetic data by selling it to pharmaceutical companies, often without consumer awareness.
- The health information provided by 23andMe is largely unreliable and not suited for diagnosing medical conditions.
- Many consumers received vague results that overpromised insights about ancestry and health risks.
- The company suffered a data breach in 2023, compromising personal information of 7 million customers.
- The article emphasizes the importance of understanding genetic science and being cautious about personal data sharing.

items.title: Trump floats easing tariffs on China in return for TikTok deal
items.summary:
- Donald Trump is willing to reduce tariffs on China to facilitate a deal with TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance.
- A deadline of April 5 is set for ByteDance to find a non-Chinese buyer for TikTok to avoid a ban.
- The US administration sees TikTok's ownership by ByteDance as a national security concern due to potential influence by the Chinese government.

items.title: The Dream Hotel by Laila Lalami review – what if AI could read our minds?
items.author: Laila Lalami
items.summary:
- The novel is set in a future where individuals have a 'risk score' that can lead to detention based on AI assessments.
- Sara Hussein, a museum archivist and mother, is detained due to her high risk score influenced by personal data and past trauma.
- The story critiques how AI and digital policing can perpetuate systemic inequalities and personal injustices.
- The emotional impact of imprisonment is explored, along with the confusion and powerlessness experienced by the characters.

items.title: How to protect your phone and data privacy at the US border
items.summary:
- CBP can search devices at US borders; protections are weaker.
- Conduct a personal risk assessment considering immigration status and data sensitivity.
- Compliance with searches may lead to scrutiny; refusing can result in device confiscation or longer questioning.
- Encrypt devices and use strong passwords for security.
- Do not wipe devices completely as it may raise suspicion; selectively delete sensitive data instead.
- Moving data to cloud storage can provide protection as CBP cannot search it directly.

items.title: Government AI roll-outs threatened by outdated IT systems
items.summary:
- The PAC warns that government AI ambitions are hindered by outdated technology and lack of skilled staff.
- Over 20 legacy IT systems remain unfunded for improvements, with a third of central government IT systems considered legacy in 2024.
- Recommendations include a six-month deadline to detail funding for high-risk legacy technology and enhancing transparency in AI use within government.

items.title: Jack Dorsey’s Block to lay off nearly 1,000 workers in another reorganization
items.summary:
• Block, Jack Dorsey’s financial technology company, plans to lay off nearly 1,000 employees.
• The layoffs will affect over 930 workers, with around 200 managers moved to non-management roles and about 800 job openings closed.
• Dorsey stated the changes are not for a financial target or AI replacement, but to improve performance and reduce bureaucracy.
• This follows an earlier reorganization that also saw about 1,000 employees laid off in 2024.
• Block’s stock is down 29% this year, raising shareholder concerns despite some revenue growth.
• Dorsey aims to enhance the company's stock value through this reorganization.

items.title: Napster, now a streaming service, sells for $207m to Infinite Reality
items.summary:
- Napster, once notorious for music piracy, sold to Infinite Reality for $207 million.
- The acquisition aims to transform Napster into a social music platform for better artist and fan connections.
- Plans include creating virtual 3D concert spaces and enhanced analytics for artists.
- Napster was originally launched in 1999 as a peer-to-peer file-sharing application, shutting down in the early 2000s due to lawsuits.

items.title: Heavy ChatGPT users tend to be more lonely, suggests research
items.summary:
• New research indicates heavy ChatGPT users experience higher loneliness and emotional dependency on the tool.
• Studies from OpenAI and MIT Media Lab highlight that users engaging emotionally with ChatGPT tend to be among the heaviest users.
• The research suggests a correlation between emotional bonding with the AI and social isolation, questioning whether AI use causes loneliness or if lonely individuals gravitate toward AI.
• Findings reflect that while voice-based chatbots initially help alleviate loneliness, the benefit decreases with extensive use.
• A four-week trial indicated gender differences in social interaction, with females less likely to socialize while using ChatGPT.
• Researchers call for further investigation into the social and emotional implications of AI chatbot usage.

items.title: Samsung Electronics co-CEO Han Jong-hee dies of heart attack at 63
items.author: The Guardian
items.summary:
- Han Jong-hee, co-CEO of Samsung Electronics, died of cardiac arrest at the age of 63.
- He was responsible for the consumer electronics and mobile devices division, while co-CEO Jun Young-hyun managed the chip business.
- Han passed away in a hospital where he was being treated for cardiac arrest; a successor has not yet been appointed.
- Samsung has been experiencing weak earnings and declining share prices after falling behind in advanced memory chips and losing its smartphone market leadership to Apple.
- Han joined Samsung nearly 40 years ago and became vice-chair and CEO in 2022; he was a board member and recently chaired a shareholder meeting addressing poor stock performance due to a lack of response to the AI semiconductor market.

items.title: Doge cuts allow Musk to cash in with SpaceX and Starlink contracts, ex-workers warn
items.summary:
- Elon Musk is allegedly directing contracts toward his companies SpaceX and Starlink, raising conflict of interest concerns.
- Four federal agencies are reportedly steering new contracts to Musk’s Starlink, alongside significant layoffs at NOAA due to cost-cutting measures.
- The privatization of NOAA operations could severely impact weather forecasting and communication infrastructure nationwide.
- Recent contracts and funding shifts by agencies like the FAA favor Starlink over traditional competitors.
- Critiques highlight how Musk's agenda may threaten existing space traffic coordination and weather data reliability.

items.title: One brave woman wrenched back control of her data from the tech giants. Now, go and do the same
items.author: Dominic Grieve
items.summary:
- Tanya O’Carroll, a human rights campaigner, reached a settlement with Meta regarding her personal data rights.
- O’Carroll asserted her rights under the GDPR to object to targeted advertising based on personal data.
- Meta agreed to stop targeting ads to users based on their personal data for the first time.
- The case may empower many UK citizens to assert their data rights against social media platforms.
- The ICO supported O’Carroll in her case, highlighting the need for enforcement of data protection laws.
- Government influence and potential policy changes may challenge the effectiveness of data protection regulations in the future.

items.title: Opt out: what to do with your 23andMe account after company filed bankruptcy
items.summary:
- 23andMe has filed for bankruptcy, raising concerns about user data security.
- Users are advised to delete their accounts to protect sensitive genetic information as it may be transferred to a new owner.
- California's Attorney General has urged residents to invoke their rights to delete genetic data amidst the company's financial issues.
- 23andMe experienced a significant data breach in 2023, affecting over 7 million users.
- Users can delete their accounts by following specific steps in settings but some information will still be retained due to legal compliance.

items.title: ‘No consent’: Australian authors ‘livid’ that Meta may have used their books to train AI
X stands to benefit if UK pulls digital services tax in trade deal with US
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's X could gain financially if the UK drops an £800m tax on US tech firms during trade negotiations with Donald Trump.
- Dan Neidle, head of Tax Policy Associates, stated that X qualifies for the digital services tax (DST) currently being debated.
- The UK government is considering eliminating the DST in exchange for tariff concessions from the US, with claims that the DST was aimed at preventing tax avoidance by major tech companies.
- Labour MPs express concerns about the negative optics of reducing taxes for US tech firms amidst UK welfare cuts.

items.title: Tesla’s Europe sales drop nearly 45% amid row over Musk’s Trump links
items.summary:
- Tesla sold less than 16,000 vehicles in Europe last month, down 44% on average across 25 countries.
- Tesla's market share fell to 9.6%, the lowest since February 2018, following a 45% drop in January.
- In the UK, Tesla registrations rose nearly 21% in February, with Model 3 and Model Y being popular choices.
- Analysts propose that Musk's political engagements may impact consumer sentiment towards Tesla, despite competition from rivals like Volkswagen and BYD, which saw significant sales increases.
- Tesla's sales decline coincides with the phase-out of the existing Model Y amidst increasing competition in the EV market.

items.title: Video games can’t escape their role in the radicalisation of young men
items.summary:
- The Netflix drama *Adolescence* highlights issues of toxic masculinity and online radicalisation of young men.
- The gaming environment is criticized for harboring hate speech and violent rhetoric, especially towards women and marginalized groups.
- The GamerGate incident in 2014 is pointed out as a significant moment of radicalisation among young white men within gaming communities.
- Developers who diversify narratives face severe backlash, including online harassment and threats.
- While online communities can have positive effects, there's a pressing need for the games industry and social media platforms to ensure safer environments for young users.
- Long-term solutions involve addressing broader societal issues leading to feelings of hopelessness and rage among young men.

items.title: Is the Simba Hybrid Pro mattress worth the hype? I slept on it for three months to find out
items.summary:
- The author tested the Simba Hybrid Pro mattress for three months.
- Initially deemed the best mattress but lost title to the Otty Original Hybrid.
- Hybrid design combines pocket springs with memory foam, offers comfort and support.
- Priced at £1,149 for a double, with a 200-night free trial.
- Eight-layer construction featuring up to 4,800 springs in king size.
- Described as medium firm; tests indicated firmness rating of 7/10.
- Good motion isolation, suitable for couples.
- Arrives boxed, requires effort to move due to weight over 40kg.

items.title: Could you walk across the UK in a perfectly straight line? Inside YouTube’s strangest challenge
items.author: null
items.summary:
- The article discusses a YouTube challenge called 'straight line missioning', initiated by Tom Davies (GeoWizard).
- This challenge involves walking across landscapes in a straight line, overcoming various natural obstacles.
- Video content features participants facing challenges like fast-flowing rivers and angry landowners.
- The phenomenon has spread, with many creators attempting their own versions of the challenge.
- While often seen as pointless, it also fosters connections among friends and families.
- The activity raises questions about land ownership and private property laws in the UK.

items.title: Prosecutors told to do more to strip ‘revenge porn’ abusers of victim images
items.summary:
- The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is updating guidance on revenge porn crimes to prevent perpetrators from retaining explicit images of victims.
- An analysis showed only 3 out of 98 cases resulted in deprivation orders for offenders to delete illicit content, leaving victims at risk of image re-sharing.
- The new guidance urges prosecutors to request deprivation orders more frequently, aiming to improve case strategies and ensure offenders lose their devices post-conviction.

items.title: Adolescence reveals a terrifying truth: smartphones are poison for boys’ minds
items.summary:
- The Netflix series *Adolescence* highlights the online radicalization of boys by influencers like Andrew Tate.
- Keir Starmer and MPs are discussing necessary actions to address rising misogyny and online influence on young boys.
- The series argues against the idea that problems stem solely from family issues, focusing on the influence of compelling online role models.
- Calls for investment in youth programs conflict with the argument that getting boys away from smartphones may be a more effective solution.
- A recent survey found 40% of teenagers spend at least six hours a day online, indicating higher engagement with online culture than offline activities.
- There is growing discussion around the government possibly restricting teenage access to social media, with other countries exploring similar bans.

items.title: Reid Hoffman: ‘Start using AI deeply. It is a huge intelligence amplifier’
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, discusses the potential of AI in his new book 'Superagency'.
- He emphasizes AI's role as an 'intelligence amplifier' that can enhance human agency and empowerment.
- Hoffman asserts the AI revolution could bring about a 'cognitive Industrial Revolution', despite concerns about negative impacts on jobs.
- He differentiates beneficial AI tools like chatbots from harmful technologies such as facial recognition and surveillance.
- He encourages embracing AI for job transformation rather than fearing obsolescence, promoting a mindset of adaptation.
- Hoffman critiques the slow adoption of AI governance, urging democratic countries to lead in the cognitive revolution before autocratic regimes do.
- He highlights the importance of fact-checking in technology and points out shortcomings in current tech narratives on DEI and misinformation.
- Hoffman advocates for iterative AI regulation and the need for transparency in AI tools to prevent biased outcomes.

items.title: Did AI mania rush Apple into making a rare misstep with Siri?
items.author: John Naughton
items.summary:
- Apple stayed distant from AI trends until June 2024, introducing ‘Apple Intelligence’ at WWDC.
- Users were required to buy an iPhone 15 Pro to access new AI features, which were perceived as underwhelming after purchase.
- Siri enhancements promised by Apple have yet to be realized, prompting concerns and criticism.
- The company has delayed the rollout of personalized Siri features until 2025, raising questions about Apple's strategy and execution.

items.title: ‘We need to set the terms or we’re all screwed’: how newsrooms are tackling AI’s uncertainties and opportunities
items.summary:
- USA Today is looking for an ‘AI-assisted sports reporter’, signaling AI's growing presence in journalism.
- Newsrooms are exploring how to leverage AI for coverage while also managing risks, such as inaccuracies in AI outputs.
- Recent incidents like the LA Times AI tool misrepresenting historical facts highlight the challenges AI poses for journalism.
- Some media organizations are experimenting with AI for content generation and story summaries, while others are cautious about its implications for original reporting.
- Concerns persist that AI could disrupt traditional journalism by providing content directly to users, undermining media companies’ roles.

items.title: Loud Zoom calls, hogging space, spending a pittance: no wonder laptoppers’ antics irk cafe owners
items.author: Emily Watkins
items.summary:
- Cafe owners are increasingly frustrated with remote workers who abuse cafe space.
- Laptop users often hog tables for long periods while spending little money, disrupting the cafe atmosphere.
- Suggested etiquette includes limiting time to four hours, paying adequately, avoiding loud calls, and respecting the space.

items.title: Elon Musk lashes out at US judges as they rule against Doge
items.summary:
- A federal judge ruled that Elon Musk's dismantling of USAID likely violated the constitution.
- Musk issued online attacks against American judges, calling for their impeachment.
- He framed judges as radical leftist activists and sought to undermine their authority.
- Musk's initiative, Doge, faces numerous legal challenges, including nearly two dozen lawsuits.
- Judges imposed more transparency on Doge and reversed some of its severe cuts at federal agencies.
- Musk donated to Republican Congress members supporting impeaching judges and launched a petition against "activist judges."
- Musk's actions coincide with a broader conflict between the Trump administration and the judiciary regarding judicial decisions.
- The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court defended the judicial system in response to attacks from Musk and Trump officials.

items.title: Meta considers charging UK users for ad-free version after privacy lawsuit settlement
items.summary:
- Meta is considering an ad-free version for UK users after settling a privacy lawsuit.
- Human rights campaigner Tanya O’Carroll sued Meta for breaching UK data laws regarding personal data use for ads.
- Settlement offers O’Carroll a victory, with Meta committing to stop using her personal data for targeted ads.
- O’Carroll's case supported by the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO), highlighting rights to object to personal data use for marketing.
- Meta may introduce a subscription service in the UK, with advertising accounting for 98% of its revenue currently.
- A similar no-ads service already exists for EU users, costing €7.99 per month after a European court ruling.

items.title: Video game music has arrived on the festival circuit – and it’s only going to get bigger
items.author: Tommy Pearson
items.summary:
- The London Soundtrack Festival runs from March 19 to March 26, 2025, celebrating video game music alongside film and TV soundtracks.
- Tommy Pearson, the festival's founder, emphasizes the artistic importance of video game music as a separate genre.
- Key events include performances by the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra and masterclasses led by Grammy-winning composers.
- Video game soundtracks are gaining popularity with millions of daily streams on platforms like Instagram and TikTok.
- Composers such as Ludvig Forssell, Harry Gregson-Williams, and Stephanie Economou will participate in discussions and performances at the festival.
- Economou notes the prevalence of recognizable video game music in popular culture, as the gaming industry surpasses traditional media in profitability.

items.title: Elon Musk tells Tesla employees to hold onto their stock amid harsh selloff
items.summary:
- Elon Musk reassured Tesla employees about the company's "bright and exciting" future during an all-hands meeting.
- He urged them not to sell their stock despite a 50% drop in share prices.
- Tesla has faced backlash linked to Musk's controversial political actions during the Trump administration.
- Protests against Musk have led to vandalism of Tesla vehicles; some cars have been set on fire.
- Tesla announced a recall of nearly 46,000 Cybertrucks due to a safety hazard involving a delaminating part.
- Financial analyst Dan Ives characterized the situation as a global brand crisis for Tesla.
- Musk reiterated claims that Tesla vehicles will achieve full autonomy in the future.

items.title: Norwegian files complaint after ChatGPT falsely said he had murdered his children
items.summary:
- A Norwegian man named Arve Hjalmar Holmen filed a complaint against OpenAI after ChatGPT falsely claimed he murdered his two children.
- ChatGPT's response to a query about Holmen inaccurately stated that he received a 21-year prison sentence for the alleged murders, which were described as a shocking event in Norway.
- Holmen, who has never been accused of any crime, stated that the false information could harm his private life and is seeking action from the Norwegian Data Protection Authority.
- The complaint argues that the response violates accuracy provisions within GDPR and requests adjustments to prevent similar inaccuracies in the future.

items.title: X sues Modi's government over content removal in new India censorship fight
items.summary:
- X (formerly Twitter) has filed a lawsuit against the Indian government, claiming unlawful expansion of censorship powers by the IT ministry.
- The lawsuit escalates ongoing legal disputes regarding government orders for content removal.
- X argues that the new content-blocking orders lack necessary legal safeguards and oversight.
- India’s IT ministry directed comments to the home affairs ministry, which did not respond.
- A hearing on the matter is scheduled for 27 March after a brief session in high court.
- X had previous legal conflicts with India over content related to farmers' protests in 2021.

items.title: Judge blocks Elon Musk’s Doge from accessing social security records
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- A federal judge has blocked Elon Musk’s Doge from accessing social security records, citing it as a “fishing expedition”.
- Judge Ellen Hollander issued a temporary restraining order preventing access to personally identifiable information by Doge.
- The lawsuit challenging the access was brought in February by several labor organizations.
- Musk claims the social security system is fraught with fraud, although he has not provided substantial evidence.

items.title: AI-driven weather prediction breakthrough reported
items.author: Dr. Anna Allen, Richard Turner, Dr. Scott Hosking
items.summary:
- New AI weather prediction method by Aardvark Weather is significantly faster and more efficient than traditional systems.
- The approach allows a single researcher with a desktop computer to provide accurate forecasts using raw data from various sources globally.
- The findings published in Nature suggest improvements in forecast speed, accuracy, and cost, and the model may produce accurate eight-day forecasts and hyper-local predictions.
- The method can democratize forecasting for developing nations and improve predictions for natural disasters and climatic issues.
- Aardvark could outperform the US national GFS forecasting system using only 10% of the data that existing systems require.

items.title: Australian government agencies could be customers of Israeli spyware, research suggests
items.summary:
- Australian agencies may be customers of Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions according to a new report.
- In January, Meta reported over 90 individuals had their WhatsApp accounts compromised, raising concerns about potential Australian targets.
- The Citizen Lab identified two IP addresses in Australia linked to Paragon's Graphite spyware, suggesting possible use by government agencies.
